headline: Ohio’s Republican Senate primary attracts big money as tensions boil over ahead of Saturday Trump rally
author: Taylor Giorno
sentences:
If Mandel supporters do decide to attend, the group added, “Booing is entirely appropriate!”
Ohio Value Voters embedded a Club for Growth ad in their message that highlighted the “vile and derogatory comments” Vance previously made about Trump.

Protect Ohio Values also directly targeted Mandel in its political advertising, compiling clips of the Senate hopeful praising politicians like Sen. Mitt Romney (R-Utah) who they believe contradict Mandel’s “anti-establishment” message.
Candidates with large pockets or influential allies have defined the race, but on May 3, Ohio Republicans will decide which candidate they want to place on the ballot for November’s general election.

The outside spending group has paid for digital advertising, research and polling, data modeling, and other activities to craft political messages intended to influence Ohio voters.
After Thiel’s latest donation, the pro-Vance PAC paid vendors almost $2.2 million, including $1.6 million additional dollars to Flexpoint Media LLC for TV and digital ad placement.
With $3.6 million left over from his 2018 Senate bid, Mandel is the only Republican candidate who has not reported using his own funds in a race largely defined by self-funding.

He donated $10 million to Protect Ohio Values in March 2021, and Per Aspera Policy, a “dark money” group tied to Thiel, also donated $200,000 earlier this year.
Former President Donald Trump and PayPal co-founder turned billionaire tech investor Peter Thiel want Ohio voters to choose “Hillbilly Elegy” author J.D.
Thiel has poured at least $13.5 million into Protect Ohio Values, a pro-Vance super PAC almost entirely funded by the inventor or groups tied to Thiel.

The USA Freedom Fund Independent, a super PAC that spent over $660,000 in support of Mandel, spent more than $3 million against Gibbons this cycle.
The Club, which recently endorsed Mandel, spent most of that money against Mandel’s Republican opponents, including $1.6 million against Vance.
Numerous outside spending groups support Mandel, including the Republican Party of Shelby County, which spent more than $1 million for Mandel.
Mike Gibbons is jockeying for first place in the polls and has a larger war chest than any other candidate due to his enormous self-funding.
The winning Republican will face off with the winner of the Democratic primary, likely either Morgan Harper or U.S. Rep. Tim Ryan (D-Ohio).
Dolan, a former Ohio state senator, self-financed almost $10.6 million of the $11.2 million his campaign has raised ahead of the primary.
Polls indicate the share of undecided voters in Ohio is narrowing, down from one-quarter of voters last month to 13% in April.
Despite the public feud playing out between Mandel and Vance’s allies, other contenders also have a shot at the nomination.
Trump Jr. attacked the Club, which he referred to as the “Club for Chinese Growth” in a recent tweet, for backing Mandel.
A recent poll found Vance trailing Josh Mandel, a far-right candidate and former Ohio state treasurer, by 5 points.
Of the $17.7 million his campaign reportedly raised, just under $16.7 million comes from candidate self-financing.
Trump endorsed Vance last Friday and Trump’s son, Donald Trump Jr., joined Vance on the campaign trail this week.
And while the Cook Political Report rated the open seat as leaning right, a Republican victory is not inevitable.
Mandel raised $2.6 million this cycle for his Senate bid this cycle, narrowly surpassing Vance’s $2.5 million.
On May 3, Ohio voters will choose a Republican candidate after an expensive, contentious U.S. Senate primary.
The final candidate, Neil Patel, has raised just over $82,000, including more than $28,000 of his own money.
Former Ohio GOP chair Timken self-financed $3.5 million of the almost $7.9 million her campaign has raised.
A conservative 01(c)(4) nonprofit, Ohio Value Voters, asked supporters to boycott Saturday’s Trump rally.
Rob Portman (R-Ohio) in a race expected to be one of the most expensive of the 2022 election cycle.
Thiel made headlines this week with an additional $3.5 million donation after Trump endorsed Vance.
The Club’s super PAC, Club for Growth Action, has spent over $4.6 million in the Ohio Senate race.
The Vance campaign will join Trump at a Save America rally in Delaware County on Saturday.
Contenders Matt Dolan and Jane Timken also significantly self-financed their campaigns.
Patel received more than half of his donations, $48,684, from large individual donors.
But a key endorsement and a super PAC may not be enough to secure a victory for Vance.
But Vance is just one in a crowded field of seven candidates vying to replace Sen.
Mike Pukita has raised significantly less money than the five frontrunners.
Protect Ohio Values already spent over $12.3 million this election cycle.
Club for Growth Action spent an additional $1.3 million against Gibbons.
Pukita self-financed $477,527 of the $501,989 his campaign raised.
